thread.title: Donald Trump, Australia, Betsy DeVos: Your Thursday Briefing
thread.title_full: Donald Trump, Australia, Betsy DeVos: Your Thursday Briefing

author: SEAN ALFANO
title: Donald Trump, Australia, Betsy DeVos: Your Thursday Briefing
text:
• New Zealand has released documents tied to its approval of Peter Thiel’s 2011 application for citizenship . Mr. Thiel, a billionaire tech investor and adviser to Mr. Trump, wrote that the country shared his view of “the future” but that he did not intend to live there — raising questions about the New Zealand government’s motivation. • It’s tax season in the U.S. , and IBM’s Watson is being deployed by H&R Block as a virtual assistant . Watson’s training included reading the more than 74,000 pages of the federal tax code and thousands of tax-return questions culled from six decades of H&R Block data. • U.S. stocks were up slightly on Wednesday. Here’s a snapshot of global markets Market Snapshot Noteworthy • A refugee’s story. “This country took me and my family in when we were at one of the lowest points of our lives and returned to me a feeling I had lost: that of being safe.” That’s Helene Cooper, a Washington reporter for The Times, describing her family’s harrowing effort to reach the U.S. from Liberia in 1980 . • In memoriam. Bharati Mukherjee , 76, an Indian-born American writer who explored the internal clashes of her immigrant characters in the award-winning collection “The Middleman and Other Stories” and in novels like “Jasmine.” 
Advertisement And Lennart Nilsson , a Swedish photographer whose micro-cameras bared some of life’s breathtaking moments — most memorably a human embryo’s maturation. He was 94. • Partying with Migos. The hip-hop act has a No. 1 hit on the Billboard chart with “Bad and Boujee.” Our 360 video takes you onstage with the group. • Beyoncé is pregnant with twins … … and Twitter is abuzz with congratulatory messages. Some of the tweets, like ones from the restaurant chains Popeyes and Denny’s , though, were somewhat puzzling. Smarter Living • New Year’s resolutions: For all of February, Smarter Living is here to help you stick to your goals. More than 600 of you wrote in since we started on Monday , discussing everything from losing weight and getting fit to resolving to build a boat (yes, a boat). We’ve rounded up some of our favorites . A few trends emerged, so here are a few helpful articles about fitness / nutrition / weight loss ; personal finances ; mental health , and productivity / time management . And if your goal doesn’t fit into those categories, no sweat: Our tips this month will be helpful no matter your resolution. • Recipe of the day: Baked potatoes and creamed braising greens work as sides or as a meal. Back Story Does it matter whether a groundhog knows when spring will arrive? Whether or not Punxsutawney Phil sees a shadow today in Pennsylvania, the vernal equinox is less than seven weeks away. While Groundhog Day is popular in the U.S., there are harbingers of the season elsewhere that don’t involve a rodent. Photo Punxsutawney Phil, the weather prognosticating groundhog, with a handler on Feb. 2, 2015. Credit Gene J. Puskar/Associated Press The Bosnian tradition of Cimburijada , also known as the Festival of Scrambled Eggs, celebrates the first day of spring with a supersize breakfast. In Alaska, the Nenana Ice Classic is a statewide contest with a six-figure jackpot for correctly guessing when the Nenana River’s ice will break — sometime between mid-April and mid-May is typical. 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story But there’s a celebration in the Royal Burgh of Lanark, Scotland, that stands apart for its unique name: Whuppity Scoorie. On every first of March, children swing balls of paper on a string tied around their heads while running three times around the town’s church bell. Whuppity Scoorie’s origins are unclear, but some view it as a pagan festival meant to drive out evil and welcome spring. The townspeople don’t seem to mind the ambiguity. “That’s the great thing about it,” a longtime resident once said. “You make up your own myth.” Remy Tumin contributed reporting.
